rules.title: Impair Defenses – Hooking and Hiding Artifacts via Common Utilities

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'This is a test command'

attacks.description: Intermediate command using python to print a message, simulating execution of user-supplied input
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'User Execution Test' to the console

attacks.description: Advanced scenario creating a script, making it executable, and then running it, simulating a more complex user execution attack
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script named malicious.sh in /tmp, makes it executable, and then executes it, printing 'Malicious payload' to the console

attacks.description: Decodes a mock payload from a text file and saves it as an executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new executable file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Writes a mock payload to a DLL file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new DLL file in the temp directory

attacks.expected_behavior: Registers the DLL and loads it into memory

attacks.description: Basic example of loading a kernel module and decrypting a payload using openssl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The kernel module is loaded, and the encrypted payload is decrypted and saved as a binary file.

attacks.description: Intermediate example assuming internet access for downloading a payload, extracting it, loading a kernel module, and executing a loader script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload is downloaded, extracted, the kernel module is loaded, and the loader script is executed, potentially leading to payload installation.

attacks.command: echo 'kernel module source code' > /tmp/module.c; gcc /tmp/module.c -o /tmp/module.ko; insmod /tmp/module.ko; openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -in /tmp/payload.enc -out /tmp/payload.bin
attacks.description: Advanced example involving the compilation of a custom kernel module from source code, loading it, and then decrypting an encrypted payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: A custom kernel module is compiled and loaded, and an encrypted payload is decrypted, demonstrating a complex payload installation scenario.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Stop the Windows Defender service to simulate disabling a security tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Defender service will be stopped, simulating the disabling of a security tool.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Disable Windows Defender's real-time monitoring using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Windows Defender's real-time monitoring will be disabled.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Attempt to modify the Windows Registry to disable Windows Defender, simulating an advanced evasion technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key will be modified to disable Windows Defender, demonstrating an advanced evasion technique.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Attempt to disable Apache by removing execution permissions, simulating defense evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Apache service fails to start or run due to lack of execution permissions.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Stop AppArmor, a Linux security module, to simulate disabling a security tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: AppArmor service is stopped, potentially reducing system security.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Rename systemd to simulate modifying a critical system tool, potentially impairing system defenses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Systemd is renamed, which could cause system instability or failure to boot if not properly restored.

attacks.description: Attempt to stop Windows Defender service to impair system defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to stop the Windows Defender service, which could impair system defenses if successful. Requires admin privileges.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to stop the Windows Defender service, impairing system defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses PowerShell to stop the Windows Defender service, which is a critical system defense. It requires admin privileges and could significantly impair system security if successful.

attacks.description: Disable the Windows Defender service startup to impair system defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to disable the Windows Defender service from starting, which would impair system defenses. It requires admin privileges and could have significant security implications if successful.

attacks.description: Hides a file by creating a function in the bashrc file to unlink the file, then sources the bashrc to apply the changes and calls the function to hide the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified file will be unlinked (deleted) from the system, potentially evading detection.

attacks.description: Modifies the Linux kernel parameter to ignore all ICMP echo requests, potentially impairing network defenses that rely on ping responses for host discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will ignore all ICMP echo requests, affecting network scanning and discovery techniques.

attacks.description: Preloads a potentially malicious library before executing the ls command, demonstrating how an attacker could impair defenses by manipulating the dynamic linker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious library will be loaded into memory, potentially allowing an attacker to evade detection or execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Basic command to test the execution of a command via a web service-like interface, writing to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the TEMP directory with the content 'TestCommand'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that fetches a command from a hypothetical local web server and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a command from a local web server (if running) and executes it. This demonstrates command and control via web services.

attacks.description: Advanced command setting up a simple HTTP listener to receive and execute commands, simulating a web service for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts an HTTP listener on localhost:8080, waiting for incoming requests. Upon receiving a request, it responds with 'Command executed' and closes the connection. This demonstrates setting up a local web service for command and control purposes.

attacks.description: Basic command to demonstrate interacting with a web service for command and control using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified URL with the data 'test', simulating command and control communication.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using wget to interact with a web service, passing arguments.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the content from the specified URL, passing an argument, and discards the output, simulating a covert command and control channel.

attacks.description: Advanced command demonstrating the use of curl to upload a configuration file to a web service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uploads a local file named 'config.json' to the specified URL, simulating the upload of a malicious or benign configuration file for command and control purposes.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named date.txt in the temp directory with the current date.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate a web request using PowerShell, without actually sending the request to a malicious site.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to create a web request object in PowerShell without sending an actual request.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file in the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest cmdlet, assuming internet access for demonstration purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content of http://example.com and saves it as a file named example.html in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a file using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the test.txt file into an archive.zip file in the temporary directory, overwriting any existing file due to the -Force parameter.

attacks.description: Advanced command to remove a file using PowerShell on Linux, handling potential errors silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to remove the test.txt file from the temporary directory. If the file does not exist or cannot be removed, the command continues without error due to -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue.

attacks.command: echo "This is a test file" > "%TEMP%\test.txt" && certutil -encode "%TEMP%\test.txt" "%TEMP%\encoded.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a test file, then uses certutil to encode it, demonstrating file obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file and its encoded version will be created in the temporary directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Hello, World!' | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\obfuscated.txt' -Encoding UTF8" && powershell -Command "Get-Content -Path '%TEMP%\obfuscated.txt' -Encoding UTF8 | Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\deobfuscated.txt' -Encoding UTF8"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create an obfuscated file and then deobfuscate it, showing how data can be hidden and revealed.
attacks.expected_behavior: An obfuscated file and its deobfuscated version will be created in the temporary directory.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo This is another test > "%TEMP%\test2.txt" && certutil -f -decode "%TEMP%\test2.txt" "%TEMP%\decoded.txt"
attacks.description: Creates another test file, then uses certutil to decode it, further demonstrating obfuscation techniques.
attacks.expected_behavior: Another test file and its decoded version will be created in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encoded.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the base64 encoded string of the original test file.

attacks.description: Encrypt a test file using openssl
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encrypted.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the encrypted string of the original test file.

attacks.description: Compress a test file using gzip
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file will be compressed and replaced with a gzip archive.

attacks.description: Add a new user to simulate initial access via exploitation of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user is added to the system, simulating successful exploitation

attacks.expected_behavior: A benign file is downloaded to the temporary directory, simulating data transfer

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a file, simulating post-exploitation activity
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello, World!'

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a malicious payload using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to a temporary location

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a malicious payload using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to a temporary location

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a malicious payload using Python
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to a temporary location

attacks.description: Lists all stored credentials in the Windows Credential Manager.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials, which can include usernames and passwords for various applications and services.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "&{Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Credential Prompt'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,150); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please enter your credentials:'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $label.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,10); $form.Controls.Add($label); $textBox = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $textBox.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,30); $textBox.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(250,20); $form.Controls.Add($textBox); $button = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Button; $button.Text = 'Submit'; $button.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(100,60); $button.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(80,25); $form.Controls.Add($button); $button.Add_Click({$cred = $textBox.Text; $form.Close()}); $form.ShowDialog() | Out-Null; $cred}"
attacks.description: Prompts the user for credentials using a simple GUI form and stores the input in the $cred variable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a form prompting the user to enter credentials, which are then stored in a variable for potential further use.

attacks.description: Queries the registry for the AutoConfigURL value, which could potentially contain credentials or lead to a location where credentials are stored.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the AutoConfigURL value from the registry, if it exists, which might be used in further attacks to obtain credentials.

attacks.description: Search for password strings in /etc/ directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files containing 'password' in their contents or names within /etc/

attacks.description: Display the contents of the passwd file
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Search for database files that might store credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists database files that could potentially store credentials

attacks.description: Modifies the Userinit registry value to hijack the execution flow by adding an additional command to execute after userinit.exe, demonstrating a basic form of hijacking execution flow.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon login, the system will execute the additional command specified in the registry, potentially allowing an attacker to run arbitrary code.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Management.Automation'); $type = [System.AppDomain]::CurrentDomain.GetAssemblies() | Where-Object { $_.GetName().Name -eq 'System.Management.Automation' }; $type.GetTypes() | Where-Object { $_.Name -eq 'PSHost' } | ForEach-Object { $_.GetMethods() | Where-Object { $_.Name -eq 'EnterNestedPrompt' } | ForEach-Object { $_.Invoke($null, @()) } }"
attacks.description: Utilizes PowerShell to load the System.Management.Automation assembly and invoke a method to potentially hijack the execution flow, demonstrating an intermediate level of complexity.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to invoke a nested prompt method, which could be used to hijack execution flow within PowerShell sessions.

attacks.description: Creates a batch file in the temp directory that starts a new command prompt, demonstrating a basic form of execution flow hijacking by executing an additional command upon startup, representing an advanced scenario due to its simplicity and effectiveness.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon execution, this command creates and runs a batch file that starts a new command prompt, potentially allowing for the execution of arbitrary commands.

attacks.description: Basic example of hijacking execution flow by preloading a shared library
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command executes with the preloaded library, potentially allowing for code injection

attacks.description: Intermediate example involving compiling a malicious shared library to hijack execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The compiled library is preloaded, demonstrating a more sophisticated method of hijacking execution flow

attacks.description: Advanced scenario where the malicious code is first written to a file, then compiled and preloaded to hijack the ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: This demonstrates a complete workflow of generating, compiling, and using malicious code to hijack execution flow, posing a higher risk

attacks.description: Delete a file named indicator.txt from the %TEMP% directory using the del command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file indicator.txt will be deleted from the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Delete a file named indicator.txt from the %TEMP% directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file indicator.txt will be deleted from the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Delete a registry key named Indicator from the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software branch using the reg command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key Indicator will be deleted from the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software branch.

attacks.description: Remove the system log file to erase indicators of malicious activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The system log file will be deleted, potentially removing evidence of malicious activity.

attacks.description: Clear the authentication log file to remove indicators of unauthorized access attempts
attacks.expected_behavior: The authentication log file will be cleared, removing records of login attempts.

attacks.description: Delete all log files in /var/log to remove various indicators of malicious activity
attacks.expected_behavior: All log files in /var/log will be deleted, potentially removing a wide range of indicators of malicious activity.

attacks.description: Basic command to check for virtualization software by searching for 'virtual' in system info
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display system information related to virtualization if found.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to detect VMware processes using WMIC
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list the names and command lines of processes related to VMware if found.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "if (Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem -Property Model -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Where-Object { $_.Model -like '*Virtual*' }) { Write-Host 'Virtualization detected'; }"
attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command to detect virtualization by checking the computer model
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will write 'Virtualization detected' to the host if the computer model indicates a virtual environment.

attacks.description: Basic example to check if the system is virtual by searching for 'Virtual' in the dmidecode output.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks for virtualization by looking for 'Virtual' in the system's BIOS information.

attacks.description: Intermediate example to detect hypervisor presence by checking cpuinfo.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command looks for indicators of a hypervisor in the cpuinfo, which could suggest a virtualized environment.

attacks.description: Advanced example checking the system vendor for known virtualization platforms like VMware.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command checks the system vendor information for signs of virtualization, specifically looking for 'VMware'.

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil to potentially disguise malicious content
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the content of test.txt into encoded.txt in the temporary directory, which could be used to hide malicious data.

attacks.description: Decode a Base64 string using PowerShell to potentially retrieve hidden commands or data
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes the Base64 string 'SGVsbG8gd29ybGQ=' to 'Hello world' and writes it to hello.txt in the temporary directory, demonstrating how encoded commands could be executed.

attacks.description: Create a temporary file, encode it, and then delete the original to masquerade file activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory, encodes it into encoded.txt, and then deletes the original test.txt, demonstrating how temporary files could be used to hide malicious activity.

attacks.description: Creates a file named masquerade.txt in /tmp with restricted permissions, mimicking how a malicious file might be hidden or disguised.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named masquerade.txt will be created in /tmp with permissions that restrict access, demonstrating a basic form of masquerading.

attacks.description: Creates a hidden file owned by root, simulating a scenario where a malicious actor might try to hide files by making them owned by system users.
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden file named .hidden_file will be created in /tmp, owned by the root user, demonstrating an intermediate level of masquerading by blending in with system files.

attacks.description: Creates a hidden directory and a configuration file within it, mimicking how a malicious application might store its configuration in a way that blends in with legitimate system configurations.
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden directory .config will be created in /tmp, containing a file named masquerade.conf, demonstrating an advanced form of masquerading by mimicking application configurations.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.KeyDown += { param($sender, $e) $e.KeyCode | Out-File %TEMP%\input_capture.txt -Append }; $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Advanced command to capture keyboard input using a Windows Form and save to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures keyboard input and saves it to a temporary file

attacks.description: Basic input capture using the 'script' command to capture user input and save it to a file.

attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the Linux kernel version, showing the system's operating environment.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the base64 encoded string of 'Hello, World!'

attacks.description: Advanced scripting example using PowerShell to create and execute a script file, demonstrating file operations and process execution.

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Modify the system registry to create a new system process
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process is created and configured to start automatically on system startup

attacks.description: Start a system service
attacks.expected_behavior: The system service 'myservice' will be started.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing

attacks.description: Enable a system service to start at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The system service 'myservice' will be enabled to start at boot.

attacks.expected_behavior: The 'Test Task' is deleted, and any associated files or logs may remain.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $form.ShowDialog();"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing popup using PowerShell to test detection of suspicious GUI interactions.
attacks.expected_behavior: A popup window titled 'Phishing Simulation' appears on the screen.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing simulation test > %TEMP%\phishing_test.txt
attacks.description: Create a file in the temp directory with content that could be used to test phishing detection rules.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'phishing_test.txt' is created in the temp directory with the specified content.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$wshell = New-Object -ComObject Wscript.Shell; $wshell.Popup('Phishing simulation test',0,'Phishing Simulation',64);"
attacks.description: Use COM objects in PowerShell to simulate a phishing popup, testing detection of such interactions.
attacks.expected_behavior: A popup window with the title 'Phishing Simulation' and a warning icon appears on the screen.

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your password: ' && read password && echo 'Thank you for the password: $password' > /tmp/phish.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing command that prompts the user to enter their password and saves it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to enter their password, and then it will save the input to a file named phish.txt in the /tmp directory.

attacks.command: zenity --entry --text='Please enter your password:' --title='Phishing Alert' 2>/dev/null && echo 'Password entered.'
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing command using zenity to create a GUI prompt for the user to enter their password.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will open a GUI window prompting the user to enter their password. After entering the password and clicking OK, it will display 'Password entered.' in the terminal.

attacks.command: xterm -e 'echo Please enter your password: ; read password ; echo Thank you for the password: $password' 2>/dev/null
attacks.description: Advanced phishing command that opens a new terminal window to prompt the user for their password, making it look like a system request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will open a new terminal window with a prompt asking the user to enter their password. After entering the password and pressing Enter, the window will close.
